sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: WIM (Microsoft Windows Imaging Format) is a file-based disk image format for Windows. It is often used in Windows installers.

sections.title: Installation
sections.content: On Linux, install wimlib to work on these files.

sections.title: View information
sections.content:
To view information about the WIM file (including but not limited to: name, index, etcâ€¦), use:

```
$ wiminfo image_file
```

sections.title: Mount
sections.content: WIM as an image file can be mounted with the following command

sections.title: Unmount
sections.content:
```
# wimunmount directory --commit
```

to apply the changes in the read-write mount.

sections.title: Directory structure
sections.content:
To view the directory structure of a WIM image, use:

```
# wimdir image_file index
```

sections.title: Extract the image
sections.content:
To extract the full image, do:

```
# wimapply image_file index target_directory
```

If you only need a few files from the image, use wimextract(1).

sections.title: Compression
sections.content:
The Windows ISO is larger than 4GiB, so it cannot be copied to a boot disk formatted with the FAT32 file system, you will need to compress install.wim to do this:

```
# wimlib-imagex optimize install.wim --solid
```
